revision.comment: /* Stone (prunus) fruit tree selection guidelines to match local weather conditions */ this whole section is unencyclopaedic howto, added seven years ago and should have been removed seven years ago
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Chilling unit|the machines|Chiller|and|Water chiller}}
The '''chilling requirement''' of a fruit is the minimum period of cold [[weather]] after which a [[fruit-bearing tree]] will [[blossom]]. It is often expressed in chill hours, which can be calculated in different ways, all of which essentially involve adding up the total amount of time in a winter spent at certain temperatures.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://etweather.tamu.edu/chill/ | publisher = Texas A&M University Agricultural Research & Extension Center at Overton | title = Chilling hours}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ent.uga.edu/peach/peachhbk/pdf/physiology.pdf | title = Peach tree physiology | author = David W. Lockwood and D. C. Coston | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100610090104/http://www.ent.uga.edu/peach/peachhbk/pdf/physiology.pdf | archivedate = 2010-06-10 | df = }}</ref>
Some bulbs have chilling requirements to bloom, and some seeds have chilling requirements to sprout.
Biologically, the chilling requirement is a way of ensuring that [[vernalization]] occurs.
== Chilling units or chilling hours == A ''chilling unit'' in [[agriculture]] is a metric of a plant's exposure to chilling temperatures. Chilling temperatures extend from [[Melting point|freezing point]] to, depending on the model, {{convert|45|F|C|order=flip}} or even {{convert|60|°F|°C|order=flip}}.<ref name=BB>Byrne, D. H., and T. A. Bacon (1992). ''[http://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/stonefruit/chillacc.html Chilling estimation: its importance and estimation]''. The Texas Horticulturist 18(8):5, 8-9. Retrieved 2010-05-24.</ref> [[Drupe|Stone fruit]] trees and certain other plants of [[Temperateness|temperate climate]] develop next year's [[bud]]s in the summer. In the autumn the buds become [[dormancy|dormant]], and the switch to proper, healthy dormancy is triggered by a certain minimum exposure to chilling temperatures. Lack of such exposure results in delayed and substandard foliation, flowering and fruiting. One chilling unit, in the simplest models, is equal to one hour's exposure to the chilling temperature; these units are summed up for a whole season. Advanced models assign different weights to different temperature bands.
==Requirements==
According to Fishman, chilling in trees acts in two stages. The first is reversible: chilling helps to build up the [[precursor (chemistry)|precursor]] to dormancy, but the process can be easily reversed with a rise in temperature. After the level of precursor reaches a certain threshold, dormancy becomes irreversible and will not be affected by short-term warm temperature peaks.<ref name=SO/> [[Apple]]s have the highest chilling requirements of all fruit trees, followed by [[apricot]]s and, lastly, [[peach]]es. Apple [[cultivar]]s have a diverse range of permissible minimum chilling: most have been bred for temperate weather, but ''[[Gala (apple)|Gala]]'' and ''[[Fuji (apple)|Fuji]]'' can be successfully grown in subtropical [[Bakersfield, California]].<ref name=H87>Hall, Anthony (2001). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=vmNKZ4t7mH8C Crop responses to environment]''. CRC Press. {{ISBN|0-8493-1028-8}}. p. 87.</ref>
Peach cultivars in [[Texas]] range in their requirements from 100 chilling units (''Florida Grande'' cultivar, zoned for low chill regions) to 1,000 units (''Surecrop'', zoned for high chill regions).<ref name=KA>Kamas, J.; McEachern, J. R; Stein, L.; Roe, N. (1998). ''[http://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/extension/peach/peach.html Peach Production in Texas]'', table 1. Texas A&M University. Retrieved 2010-05-24.</ref> Planting a low-chilling cultivar in a high-chill region risks loss of a year's harvest when an early bloom is hit by a spring frost.<ref name=KA/> A high-chilling cultivar planted in a low-chill region will, quite likely, never fruit at all. A four-year study of ''Ruston Red'' [[Alabama]] peach, which has a threshold of 850 chilling units, demonstrated that a seasonal chilling deficiency of less than 50 units has no effect on harvest. Deficiency of 50 to 100 units may result in loss of up to 50% of expected harvest. Deficiency of 250 hours and more is a sure loss of practically whole harvest; the few fruit will be of very poor quality and have no market value.<ref name=PO>Powell, A. (1999). ''[http://www.aces.edu/dept/peaches/peachdormex.html Action Program for Dormex Application on Peaches]''. [[Auburn University]]. Retrieved 2010-05-24.</ref> [[Rest-breaking agent]]s (e.g. [[cyanamide|hydrogen cyanamide]], trade name ''BudPro or Dormex''), applied in spring, can partially mitigate the effects of insufficient chilling. BudPro can substitute for up to 300 hours of chilling, but an excessive spraying and timing error can easily damage the buds.<ref name=PO/> Other products such as Dormex use stabilizing compounds.
Chilling of [[Orange (fruit)|orange trees]] has two effects. First, it increases production of [[carotenoid]]s and decreases [[chlorophyll]] content of the fruit, improving their appearance and, ultimately, their market value. Second, the "quasi-dormancy" experienced by orange trees triggers concentrated flowering in spring, as opposed to more or less uniform round-the-year flowering and fruiting in warmer climates.<ref name=H87/>
[[Biennial plant]]s like [[cabbage]], [[sugar beet]], [[celery]] and [[carrot]]s need chilling to develop second-year flowering buds. Excessive chilling in the early stages of a sugar beet seedling, on the contrary, may trigger undesired growth of a flowering stem ([[Bolting (horticulture)|bolting]]) in its first year. This phenomenon has been offset by breeding sugar beet cultivars with a higher minimum chilling threshold. Such cultivars can be seeded earlier than normal without the risk of bolting.<ref name=H87/>
==Models==
All models require hourly recording of temperatures.<ref name=SO/> The simplest model assigns one chilling unit for every full hour at temperatures below {{convert|45|F|C|order=flip}}. A slightly more sophisticated model excludes freezing temperatures, which do not contribute to proper dormancy cycle, and counts only hours with temperatures between {{convert|32|F|C|order=flip}} and {{convert|45|F|C|order=flip}}.<ref name=BB/>
The Utah model assigns different weight to different temperature bands; a full unit per hour is assigned only to temperatures between {{convert|37|F|C|order=flip}} and {{convert|48|F|C|order=flip}}. Maximum effect is achieved at {{convert|7|C|F}}.<ref name=SO/> Temperatures between {{convert|55|F|C|order=flip}} and {{convert|60|F|C|order=flip}} (the threshold between chilling and warm weather) have zero weight, and higher temperature have negative weights: they reduce the beneficial effects of an already accumulated chilling hours.<ref name=BB/>
Southwick et al. wrote that neither of these models is accurate enough to account for application of [[rest-breaking agent]]s widely used in modern farming. They advocated the use of a dynamic model tailored to the two-stage explanation of dormancy.<ref name=SO>Southwick, S.; Khan, Z.; Glozer, K. (2003). ''[http://fruitsandnuts.ucdavis.edu/files/67017.pdf Evaluation of Chill Models from Historical Rest-Breaking Spray Experiments on Bing Sweet Cherry]''. [[University of California, Davis]]. Retrieved 2010-05-24.</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://harvest.ucanr.org/ Harvest Prediction Model for the counties and towns of California]. [[University of California]] Agricultural and Natural Resources. *[http://forums.gardenweb.com/forums/load/botany/msg0713574514797.html gardenweb discussion of chilling requirements] *[http://phoenixpermaculture.ning.com/forum/topics/winter-chill-data-for-phoenix?commentId=2008067%3AComment%3A156520 permaculture discussion of chilling requirements] *[http://getchill.net chill accumulation calculator for wunderground.com weather stations]
[[Category:Horticulture and gardening]] [[Category:Climate]] [[Category:Time]]

{{POV|date=November 2018}} {{essay-like|date=May 2018}}
'''Counter-mapping''' refers to efforts to [[map]] "against dominant power structures, to further seemingly progressive goals".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hodgson|first=D.L|author2=Schroeder, R.A.|title=Dilemmas of Counter-Mapping: Community Resources in Tanzania|journal=Development and Change|year=2002|volume=33|pages=79–100|doi=10.1111/1467-7660.00241}}</ref> The term was coined by Nancy Peluso<ref name="Peluso">{{cite journal|last=Peluso|first=N.L|title=Whose Woods are These? Counter-Mapping Forest Territories in Kalimantan, Indonesia|journal=Antipode|year=1995|volume=27|series=4|pages=383–406|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8330.1995.tb00286.x}}</ref> in 1995 to describe the commissioning of maps by forest users in [[Kalimantan]], [[Indonesia]], as a means of contesting state maps of forest areas that typically undermined [[indigenous peoples|indigenous]] interests. The resultant counter-hegemonic maps had the ability to strengthen forest users' resource claims.<ref name=Peluso /> There are numerous expressions closely related to counter-mapping: ethnocartography, alternative cartography, mapping-back, counter-hegemonic mapping, and public participatory mapping.<ref name=Rundstrom /> Moreover, the terms: [[critical cartography]], subversive cartography, bio-regional mapping, and remapping are sometimes used interchangeably with counter-mapping, but in practice encompass much more.<ref name=Rundstrom />
Whilst counter-mapping still primarily refers to indigenous cartographic efforts, it is increasingly being applied to non-indigenous [[map]]ping initiatives in economically developed countries.<ref name=Rundstrom /> Such counter-mapping efforts have been facilitated by processes of [[neoliberalism]],<ref name="Bryan">{{cite journal|last=Bryan|first=J|title=Walking the Line: Participatory Mapping Indigenous Rights, and Neoliberalism|journal=Geoforum|year=2011|volume=42|issue=1|pages=40–50|doi=10.1016/j.geoforum.2010.09.001}}</ref> and technological [[democratisation]].<ref name=Peluso /> Examples of counter-mapping include attempts to demarcate and protect traditional territories, community mapping, [[PPGIS|Public Participatory Geographical Information Systems]], and [[map]]ping by a relatively weak state to counter the resource claims of a stronger state.<ref name="Bauer">{{cite journal|last=Bauer|first=K|title=On the Politics and Possibilities of Participatory Mapping and GIS: Using Spatial Technologies to Study Common Property and Land Use Change Among Pastoralists in Central Tibet|journal=Cultural Geographies|year=2009|volume=16|pages=229–252|doi=10.1177/1474474008101518}}</ref> The power of counter-maps to advocate policy change in a [[Top-down and bottom-up design#Management and organization|bottom-up]] manner led commentators to affirm that counter-mapping should be viewed as a tool of [[governance]].<ref name=Alcorn />
Despite its emancipatory potential, counter-mapping has not gone without criticism. There is a tendency for counter-mapping efforts to overlook the knowledge of women, minorities, and other vulnerable, disenfranchised groups.<ref name="Rocheleau">{{cite journal|last=Rocheleau|first=D.B|author2=Edmunds, D|title=Women, Men and Trees: Gender, Power and Property in Forest and Agrarian Landscapes.|journal=World Development|year=1997|volume=25|series=8|pages=1351–1371|doi=10.1016/s0305-750x(97)00036-3}}</ref> From this perspective, counter-mapping is only empowering for a small subset of society, whilst others become further marginalised.<ref>{{cite journal|last=King|first=B.H|title=Community Participation and Geographic Information Systems|journal=The Professional Geographer|year=2004|volume=56|series=2|pages=315–317}}</ref>
== Origins ==
Nancy Peluso, professor of forest policy, coined the term 'counter-mapping' in 1995, having examined the implementation of two forest [[map]]ping strategies in [[Kalimantan]]. One set of maps belonged to state forest managers, and the [[international financial institutions]] that supported them, such as the [[World Bank]]. This strategy recognised mapping as a means of protecting local claims to territory and resources to a government that had previously ignored them.<ref name=Peluso /> The other set of maps had been created by Indonesian [[NGOs]], who often contract international experts to assist with mapping village territories.<ref name=Peluso /> The goal of the second set of maps was to co-opt the cartographic conventions of the Indonesian state, to legitimise the claims by the [[Dayak people|Dayak]] people, indigenous to Kalimantan, to the rights to forest use.<ref name=Rundstrom /> Counter-mappers in Kalimantan have acquired [[GIS]] technologies, satellite technology, and computerised [[resource management]] tools, consequently making the Indonesian state vulnerable to counter-maps.<ref name=Peluso /> As such, counter-mapping strategies in Kalimantan have led to successful community action to block, and protest against, oil palm plantations and logging concessions imposed by the central government.<ref name=Peluso />
It must, however, be recognised that counter-mapping projects existed long before coinage of the term.<ref name="Rundstrom">{{cite journal|last=Rundstrom|first=R|title=Counter-Mapping|journal=International Encyclopaedia of Human Geography|year=2009|pages=314–318}}</ref> Counter-maps are rooted in map art practices that date to the early 20th century; in the [[Mental mapping|mental maps]] movement of the 1960s; in indigenous and bioregional mapping; and parish mapping.<ref name="Wood">{{cite book|last=Wood|first=D|title=Rethinking the Power of Maps|year=2010|publisher=Guilford Press|location=London |author2=Fels, J. |author3=Krygier, J}}</ref>
=== Parish Maps Project ===
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Parish Map.jpg|thumb|right|text-top|border|alt=Salle parish map.|Salle parish map.]] -->In 1985, the charity [[Common Ground (United Kingdom)|Common Ground]] launched the [[Parish Maps Project]], a [[Top-down and bottom-up design#Management and organization|bottom-up]] initiative encouraging local people to map elements of the environment valued by their [[parish]].<ref>{{cite book|last=King|first=A|title=Holding Your Ground: An Action Guide to Local Conservation|year=1985|publisher=Penguin|location=London|author2=Clifford, S}}</ref> Since then, more than 2,500 English parishes have made such maps.<ref name=Wood /> Parish mapping projects aim to put every local person in an 'expert' role.<ref>{{cite book|last=Aberley|first=D|title=Boundaries of Home: Mapping for Local Empowerment|year=1993|publisher=New Society Publishers|location=Philadelphia}}</ref> Clifford<ref>{{cite book|last=Clifford|first=S|title=From Place to Place: Maps and Parish Maps|year=1996|publisher=Common Ground|location=London|pages=3–7|editor=Clifford, S. |editor2=King, A.|chapter=Places, People, and Parish Maps}}</ref> exemplifies this notion, affirming: "making a parish map is about creating a community expression of values, and about beginning to assert ideas for involvement. It is about taking the place in your own hands". The final map product is typically an artistic artefact, usually painted, and often displayed in village halls or schools.<ref name=perkins /> By questioning the biases of cartographic conventions and challenging predominant power effects of mapping,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Harris|first=L.M|author2=Hazen, H.D|title=Power of Maps: (Counter) Mapping for Conservation|journal=ACME|year=2006|volume=4|issue=1|pages=99–130}}</ref> The Parish Maps Project is an early example of what Peluso<ref name=Peluso /> went on to term 'counter-mapping'
== Development ==
=== Neoliberalism === The development of counter-mapping can be situated within the [[neoliberal]] political-economic restructuring of the state.<ref name=Leszcynski /> Prior to the 1960s, equipping a map-making enterprise was chiefly the duty of a single agency, funded by the national government.<ref>{{cite web|last=Goodchild|first=M,F|title=Virtual Geographic Environments as Collective Constructions|url=http://www.iseis.cuhk.edu.hk/downloads/vge/44.pdf|accessdate=4 December 2011|year=2008}}</ref> In this sense, maps have conventionally been the products of privileged knowledges.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Harley|first=J.B|title=Deconstructing the Map|journal=Cartographica|year=1989|volume=26|issue=2|pages=1–20|doi=10.3138/e635-7827-1757-9t53}}</ref> However, processes of [[neoliberalism]], predominantly since the late 1970s, have reconfigured the state's role in the cartographic project.<ref name=Bryan /> Neoliberalism denotes an emphasis on markets and minimal states, whereby individual choice is perceived to have replaced the mass-production of commodities.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Larner|first=W|title=Neoliberalism|year=2009|journal=International Encyclopaedia of Human Geography|pages=374–378}}</ref> The fact that citizens are now performing cartographic functions that were once exclusively state-controlled can be partially explained through a shift from "roll-back neoliberalism", in which the state dismantled some of its functions, to "roll-out neoliberalism", in which new modes of operating have been constructed.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Peck|first=L|author2=Tickell,A|title=Neoliberalizing Space|journal=Antipode|year=2002|volume=34|pages=380–404|doi=10.1111/1467-8330.00247}}</ref> In brief, the state can be seen to have "hollowed out" and delegated some of its [[map]]ping power to citizens.<ref name="Jessop">{{cite book|last=Jessop|first=H|title=A Handbook of Comparative Social Policy|year=2004|publisher=Edward Elgar|location=Cheltenham|pages=11–27|editor=Kennett, P|chapter=Hollowing out the 'Nation-State' and Multi-Level Governance}}</ref>
==== Counter-mapping as Neoliberal Governmentality ==== [[Governmentality]] refers to a particular form of state power that is exercised when citizens self-discipline by acquiescing to state knowledge.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Brown|first=M|author2=Knopp, L|title=Places and Polygons? Governmentality, Scale, and the Census in the Gay and Lesbian Atlas|year=2006|journal=Population, Space and Place|volume=12|pages=223–242|doi=10.1002/psp.410}}</ref> Historically, [[cartography]] has been a fundamental governmentality strategy,<ref name="Crampton">{{cite book|last=Crampton|first=J|title=Mapping: A Critical Introduction to Cartography and GIS|year=2011|publisher=John Wiley and Sons|location=London}}</ref> a technology of power, used for surveillance and control.<ref name="McCarthy">{{cite journal|last=McCarthy|first=J|title=Theorizing the State in Environmental Governance|journal=Review of International Political Economy|year=2006|volume=14|issue=1|pages=176–194|doi=10.1080/09692290601081244}}</ref> Competing claimants and boundaries made no appearance on state-led maps.<ref name=McCarthy /> This links to [[Michel Foucault|Foucault]]'s<ref name="Foucault">{{cite book|last=Foucault|first=M|title=Power/Knowledge: Selected Interviews and Other Writings:1972-1977|year=1988|publisher=Randon House|location=Canada}}</ref> notion of "subjugated knowledges" - ones that did not rise to the top, or were disqualified.<ref name=Crampton /> However, through neoliberalising processes, the state has retracted from performing some of its cartographic functions.<ref name="Leszcynski">{{cite journal|last=Leszcynski|first=A|title=Situating the Geoweb in Political Economy|journal=Progress in Human Geography|year=2011|pages=1–18}}</ref> Consequently, rather than being passive recipients of top-down map distribution, people now have the opportunity to claim sovereignty over the mapping process.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dodge|first=M|author2=Perkins, P|title=Reclaiming the Map: British Geography and Ambivalent cartographic Practice|journal=Environment and Planning A|year=2008|volume=40|issue=6|pages=|doi=10.1068/a4172}}</ref> In this new regime of neoliberal cartographic governmentality the "insurrection of subjugated knowledges" occurs,<ref name=Foucault /> as counter-mapping initiatives incorporate previously marginalised voices.
=== Technological democratisation? === In response to technological change, predominantly since the 1980s, cartography has increasingly been democratised.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rood|first=J |author2=Ormeling, F. |author3=van Elzakker, C|title=An Agenda for Democratising Cartographic Visualisation|journal=[[Norwegian Journal of Geography]]|volume=55|issue=1|pages=38–41|doi=10.1080/002919501300061427}}</ref> The wide availability of high-quality location information has enabled mass-market cartography based on [[Global Positioning System]] receivers, home computers, and the internet.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Haklay|first=M|author2=Weber, P|title=OpenStreetMap: User-Generated Street Maps|journal=Pervasive Computing|year=2008|volume=1536|pages=12–18|doi=10.1109/mprv.2008.80}}</ref> The fact that civilians are using technologies which were once elitist led Brosius ''et al''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bosius|first=P.J|title=Communities and Conservation: Histories and Politics of Community-Based Natural Resource Management|year=2005|publisher=Rowman Altamira|location=London |author2=Tsing, A.L. |author3=Zerner, C.}}</ref> to assert that counter-mapping involves "stealing the master's tools". Nevertheless, numerous early counter-mapping projects successfully utilised manual techniques, and many still use them. For instance, in recent years, the use of simple sketch mapping approaches has been revitalised, whereby maps are made on the ground, using natural materials.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Poole|first=P|title=Geomatics: Who Needs it?|journal=Cultural Survival Quarterly|year=1995|volume=18|issue=4|pages=1–77}}.</ref> Similarly, the use of scale model constructions and felt boards, as means of representing cartographic claims of different groups, have become increasingly popular.<ref name=Rocheleau /> Consequently, [[Denis Wood|Wood]] ''et al.''<ref name=Wood /> assert that counter-mappers can "make gateau out of technological crumbs".
==== Public Participation Geographical Information Systems ==== In recent years, [[Public Participation Geographical Information Systems]] (PPGIS) have attempted to take the power of the map out of the hands of the cartographic elite, putting it into the hands of the people. For instance, Kyem<ref name="Kyem">{{cite web|last=Kyem|first=K|title=Promoting Local Community Participation in Forest Management Through the Application of a Geographical Information System: A PPGIS Experience from Southern Ghana|url=http://www.ncgia.ucsb.edu/varenius/ppgis/papers/kyem/kyem.html|accessdate=2011|year=1998}}</ref> designed a PPGIS method termed Exploratory Strategy for Collaboration, Management, Allocation, and Planning (ESCMAP). The method sought to integrate the concerns and experiences of three rural communities in the Ashanti Region of Ghana into official [[forest management]] practices.<ref name=Kyem /> Kyem<ref name=Kyem /> concluded that, notwithstanding the potential of PPGIS, it is possible that the majority of the rich and powerful people in the area would object to some of the participatory uses of [[GIS]]. For example, loggers in Ghana affirmed that the PPGIS procedures were too open and democratic.<ref name=Kyem /> Thus, despite its democratising potential, there are barriers to its implementation. More recently, [[Denis Wood|Wood]] ''et al''.<ref name=Wood /> disputed the notion of PPGIS entirely, affirming that it is "scarcely [[GIS]], intensely hegemonic, hardly public, and anything but participatory".
== Counter-mapping as governance == [[Governance]] makes problematic state-centric notions of regulation, recognising that there has been a shift to power operating across several [[spatial scales]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Bridge|first=G|title=A Companion to Environmental Geography|year=2009|author2=Perreault, T|editor=Castree, N.M |editor2=Demeritt, D. |editor3=Liverman, D. |editor4=Rhoads, B|pages=475–497|chapter=Environmental Governance}}</ref> Similarly, counter-mapping complicates state distribution of [[cartography]], advocating [[Top-down and bottom-up design#Management and organization|bottom-up]] participatory mapping projects (see [[GIS and environmental governance]]). Counter-mapping initiatives, often without state assistance, attempt to exert power. As such, counter-mapping conforms to [[Bob Jessop|Jessop]]'s<ref name=Jessop /> notion of "governance without government". Another characteristic of governance is its "purposeful effort to steer, control or manage sectors or facets of society" towards a common goal.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kooiman|first=J|title=Modern Governance. New Government-Society Interactions|year=1993|publisher=Sage Publications|location=London}}</ref> Likewise, as maps exude power and authority,<ref>{{cite book|last=Colchester|first=M|title=Communities and Conservation: Histories and Politics of Community-Based Natural Resource Management|year=2005|publisher=Rowman Altamira|location=London|pages=271–304|editor=Brosius, P.J. |editor2=Tsing, A.L. |editor3=Zerner, C|chapter=Maps, Power, and the Defense of Territory: The Upper Mazarini Land Claim in Guyana}}</ref> they are a trusted medium<ref>{{cite book|last=Markham|first=B|title=West with the Night|year=1983|publisher=North Point Press|location=San Francisco}}</ref> with the ability to 'steer' society in a particular direction. In brief, [[cartography]], once the tool of kings and governments,<ref>{{cite book|last=Wood|first=D|title=The Power of Maps|year=1992|publisher=Guilford Press|location=New York}}</ref> is now being used as a tool of governance - to advocate policy change from the [[grassroots]].<ref name="Alcorn">{{cite book|last=Alcorn|first=J.B|title=Borders, Rules and Governance: Mapping to Catalyse Changes in Policy and Management|year=2000|publisher=Gatekeeper Series|location=London}}</ref> The environmental sphere is one context in which counter-mapping has been utilised as a governance tool.<ref name=Alcorn />
=== Counter-mapping as environmental governance === In contrast to expert knowledges, lay knowledges are increasingly valuable to decision-makers, in part due to the scientific uncertainty surrounding environmental issues.<ref>{{cite book|last=Evans|first=J|title=Environmental Governance|year=2012|publisher=Taylor Francis|location=London}}</ref> [[Participatory]] counter-mapping projects are an effective means of incorporating lay knowledges<ref>{{cite journal|last=Narayan|first=P|title=Empowerment through Participation: How Effective is this Approach?|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|year=2003|volume=38|issue=25|pages=21–27}}</ref> into issues surrounding [[environmental governance]]. For instance, counter-maps depicting traditional use of areas now protected for biodiversity have been used to allow resource use, or to promote public debate about the issue, rather than forcing relocation.<ref name=Alcorn /> For example, the [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] used the results of counter-mapping to advocate for the reclassification of several strictly protected areas into Indonesian national parks, including Kayan Mentarang and Gunung Lorentz.<ref name=Alcorn /> The success of such counter-mapping efforts led Alcorn<ref name=Alcorn /> to affirm that [[governance]] ([[grassroots]] mapping projects), rather than government ([[wikt:top-down|top-down]] map distribution), offers the best hope for good [[natural resource management]]. In short, it can be seen that "maps are powerful political tools in ecological and governance discussions".<ref name=Alcorn />
== Types of counter-mapping == Numerous counter-mapping types exist, for instance: protest maps, map art, counter-mapping for conservation, and [[PPGIS]]. In order to emphasise the wide scope of what has come to be known as counter-mapping, three contrasting counter-mapping examples are elucidated in this section: indigenous counter-mapping, community mapping, and state counter-mapping, respectively.
=== Indigenous counter-mapping === Counter-mapping has been undertaken most in the Third World.<ref name="perkins">{{cite journal|last=Perkins|first=C|title=Community Mapping|journal=The Cartographic Journal|volume=44|issue=2|pages=127–137|doi=10.1179/000870407x213440}}</ref> [[Indigenous peoples]] are increasingly turning to [[participatory]] mapping, appropriating both the state's techniques and manner of representation.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wainwright|first=J|author2=Bryan, J|title=Cartography, Territory, Property: Postcolonial Reflections on Indigenous Counter-Mapping in Nicaragua and Belize|journal=Cultural Geographies|year=2009|volume=16|pages=153–187|doi=10.1177/1474474008101515}}</ref> Counter-mapping is a tool for indigenous identity-building,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Taylor|first=J.J|title=Naming the Land: San Countermapping in Namibia's West Caprivi|journal=Geoforum|year=2008|volume=39|issue=5|pages=1766–1775|doi=10.1016/j.geoforum.2008.04.001}}</ref> and for bolstering the legitimacy of customary resource claims.<ref name=Peluso /> The success of counter-mapping in realising indigenous claims can be seen through Nietschmann's<ref>{{cite journal|last=Neitschmann|first=B|title=Defending the Misiko Reefs with Maps and GIS: Mapping with Sail, Scuba and Satellite|journal=Cultural Survival Quarterly|year=1995|volume=18|issue=4|pages=34–37}}</ref> assertion: {{quote box |quote = ''More indigenous territory has been claimed by maps than by guns. And more Indigenous territory can be reclaimed and defended by maps than by guns.'' |align = left |bgcolor =#FFF8E7 |quoted = 1 }} {{clear}}
==== Creation of Nunavut ==== The power of indigenous counter-mapping can be exemplified through the creation of [[Nunavut]]. In 1967, [[Frank Arthur Calder]] and the Nisaga'a Nation Tribal Council brought an action against the [[Province of British Columbia]] for a declaration that [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|aboriginal]] title to specified land had not been lawfully extinguished. In 1973, the [[Canadian Supreme Court]] found that there was, in fact, an aboriginal title. The Canadian government attempted to extinguish such titles by negotiating [[treaties]] with the people who had not signed them.<ref name=Wood /> As a first step, the [[Inuit Tapirisat of Canada]] studied [[Inuit]] land occupancy in the Arctic, resulting in the publication of the ''Inuit Land Use and Occupancy Project''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Freeman|first=M.M.R|title=Land Use and Occupancy, Vol. 1 of Inuit Land Use and Occupancy Project Report|year=1976|location=Ottawa}}</ref> Diverse interests, such as those of hunters, trappers, fishermen and berry-pickers mapped out the land they had used during their lives.<ref name=Wood /> As Usher<ref>{{cite journal|last=Usher|first=P.J|title=Environment, Race and Nation Reconsidered: Reflections on Aboriginal Land Claims in Canada|journal=Canadian Geographer|year=2003|volume=47|issue=4|pages=365–382|doi=10.1111/j.0008-3658.2003.00029.x}}</ref> noted:
{{quote box |quote = ''We were no longer mapping the 'territories' of Aboriginal people based on the cumulative observations of others of where they were…but instead, mapping the Aboriginal peoples’ own recollections of their own activities''. |align = left |bgcolor =#FFF8E7 |quoted = 1 }}
These maps played a fundamental role in the negotiations that enabled the Inuit to assert an aboriginal title to the 2 million km² in Canada, today known as Nunavut.<ref name=Wood /> Evidently, counter-mapping is a tool by which indigenous groups can re-present the world in ways which destabilise dominant representations.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kwan|first=M|title=Feminist Visualisation: Re-Envisioning GIS as a Method in Feminist Geographic Research|journal=Annals of the Association of American Geographers|volume=92|issue=4|pages=645–661|doi=10.1111/1467-8306.00309}}</ref>
=== Community mapping === [[Community]] mapping can be defined as: "local mapping, produced collaboratively, by local people and often incorporating alternative local knowledge".<ref name=perkins /> [http://www.openstreetmap.org/ OpenStreetMap] is an example of a community mapping initiative, with the potential to counter the hegemony of state-dominated map distribution.<ref>{{cite book|last=Elwood|first=S|title=Citizen Cartographies and the Shifting Politics of Expertise. Paper Presented at the 24th Annual International Cartography Conference|year=2009|location=Santiago, Chile}}</ref>
==== OpenStreetMap ==== [[File:OpenStreetMap homepage 2018 en.png|thumb|"border"text-topalt=OpenStreetMap home page.|OpenStreetMap home page.]] [[OpenStreetMap]] (OSM), a citizen-led spatial data collection website, was founded by [[Steve Coast]] in 2004. Data are collected from diverse public domain sources; of which [[GPS]] tracks are the most important, collected by volunteers with GPS receivers.<ref name=perkins /> {{as of|2011|January|10}} there were 340,522 registered OSM users, who had uploaded 2.121 billion GPS points onto the website.<ref>{{cite book|last=Perkins, C|title=Review OSM: Using and Enhancing the Free Map of the World by Ramm, F., Topf, J and Chilton, S.|year=2011|publisher=(in press)}}</ref> The process of map creation explicitly relies upon sharing and participation; consequently, every registered OSM user can edit any part of the map. Moreover, 'map parties' - social events which aim to fill gaps in coverage, help foster a community ethos.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Perkins|first=C|author2=Dodge, M|title=The Potential of User-Generated Cartography: A Case Study of the OpenStreetMap Project and Mapchester Mapping Party|journal=North West Geography|year=2008|volume=8|issue=1|pages=19–32}}</ref> In short, the [[grassroots]] OSM project can be seen to represent a [[paradigm shift]] in who creates and shares geographic information - from the state, to society.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Elwood|first=S |author2=Goodchild, M.F |author3=Sui, D.Z|title=Researching VGI: Spatial Data, Geographic Research and New Social Practice|journal=Annals of the Association of American Geographers|year=2011|pages=1–20|doi=10.1080/00045608.2011.595657}}</ref> However, rather than countering the state-dominated cartographic project, some commentators have affirmed that OSM merely replicates the 'old' socio-economic order.<ref name="Haklay">{{cite journal|last=Haklay|first=M|title=How Good is Volunteered Geographical Information? A Comparative Study of OpenStreetMap and Ordnance Survey Datasets|journal=Environment and Planning B: Planning and Design|year=2008|volume=37|pages=682–703|doi=10.1068/b35097}}</ref> For instance, Haklay<ref name=Haklay /> affirmed that OSM users in the United Kingdom tend not to map council estates; consequently, middle-class areas are disproportionately mapped. Thus, in opposition to notions that OSM is a radical cartographic counter-culture,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kent|first=A.J|title=Cartographic Blandscapes and the New Noise: Finding the Good View in a Topographical Mashup|journal=SoC Bulletin|year=2008|volume=42|pages=29–38}}</ref> are contentions that OSM "simply recreates a mirror copy of existing [[topographic mapping]]".<ref>{{cite book|last=Dodge|first=M|title=Rethinking Maps: New Frontiers in Cartographic Theory|year=2009|publisher=Routledge|location=London |author2=Perkins, C. |author3=Kitchin, R}}</ref>
=== State counter-mapping === What has come to be known as counter-mapping is not limited to the activities of [[Stateless nation|non-state]] actors within a particular nation-state; relatively weak states also engage in counter-mapping in an attempt to challenge other states.<ref name="Nevins">{{cite journal|last=Nevins|first=J|title=Contesting the Boundaries of International Justice: State Countermapping and Offshore Resource Struggles Between East-Timor and Australia|journal=Economic Geography|year=2004|volume=80|issue=1|pages=470–484}}</ref>
==== Competing cartographic representations: East Timor versus Australia ==== [[East Timor]]'s on-going effort to gain control of gas and oil resources from Australia, which it perceives at its own, is a form of counter-mapping. This dispute involves a cartographic contestation of Australia's mapping of the seabed resources between the two countries.<ref name=Nevins /> As Nevins<ref name=Nevins /> contends: whilst Australia's map is based on the status quo - a legacy of a 1989 agreement between Australia and the Indonesian occupier of East Timor at that time, East Timor's map represents an enlarged notion of what its sea boundaries should be, thereby entailing a redrawing of the map. This form of counter-mapping thus represents a claim by a relatively weak state, East Timor, to territory and resources that are controlled by a stronger state, Australia.<ref name=Rundstrom /> However, Nevins<ref name=Nevins /> notes that there is limited potential of realising a claim through East Timor's counter-map: counter-mapping is an effective strategy only when combined with broader legal and political strategies.<ref name=Nevins />
== Criticisms == Counter-mapping's claim to incorporate counter-knowledges, and thereby empower traditionally disempowered people, has not gone uncontested.<ref>{{cite book|last=Turow|first=J|title=Playing Doctor: Television, Storytelling, and Medical Power|year=2010|publisher=The University of Michigan Press|location=Michigan}}</ref> A sample of criticisms leveled at counter-mapping:
* Counter-mapping fails to recognise that community is a constantly shifting, fluid process, too often relying on a notion of community as bounded and fixed. As such, the process of mapping communicates and naturalises who does, and who does not, belong within particular boundaries.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kosek|first=J|title=Mapping Politics|journal=Quarterly Publication of the International Association for the Study of Common Property|year=1998|volume=45|pages=4–6}}</ref> * Due to the power imbalance between [[indigenous peoples|indigenous]] claims and those of the state, the language and tools of the dominant society must be used by those under its control. The process of using another's tools can change the ideas represented, resulting in a map of unpredictable quality.<ref name=Rundstrom /> * Counter-mapping is in danger of becoming the 'thing to do'; a "magic bullet applied uncritically".<ref>{{cite book|last=Fox|first=J|title=Mapping Communities: Ethics, Values, Practice|year=2005|publisher=East-West Center|location=Hawaii |author2=Suryanata, K. |author3=Hershock, P.}}</ref> * There is a geography to the success of counter-mapping. In Tibet, counter-mapping is of limited political utility as [[mapmaking]] is not enfranchised and cannot be scaled up, for instance, to settle legal battles over land tenure and resource rights through the regulatory offices of the state.<ref name=Bauer /> * Counter-mapping projects utilising [[GIS]] require significant knowledge and [[computer literacy]] above that of lay individuals.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Milla|first=K.A |author2=Lorenzo, A. |author3=Brown,C|title=GIS, GPS, and Remote Sensing Technologies in Extension Services: Where to Start, What to Know|journal=Extension Journal|year=2005|volume=43|issue=3}}</ref> * Investment in specialised computers and software often results in prohibitive mapping costs for a large majority of local people, particularly in poor areas. As some groups prove more capable of adopting the technologies than others, counter-mapping projects can deepen divisions within communities along gender and economic lines.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Corbett|first=J.M |author2=Chaplin, L. |author3=Gibson, G.R|title=Indigenous Mapping|journal=International Encyclopaedia of Human Geography|year=2009|pages=377–382}}</ref>
To summarise, whilst counter-mapping has the potential to transform map-making from "a science of princes",<ref>{{cite journal|last=Harley|first=J.B|title=Silences and Secrecy: The Hidden Agenda of Cartography in Early Modern Europe|journal=Imago Mundi, Ltd|year=1988|volume=40|pages=57–76|doi=10.1080/03085698808592639}}</ref> the investment required to create a map with the ability to challenge state-produced cartography means that counter-mapping is unlikely to become a "science of the masses".<ref name=Peluso />
